metadata.title: The Links Between Industrial, Community, and Ecological Sustainability: A Forestry Case Study

relevance.topic: Industrial, Community, and Ecological Sustainability in Forestry
relevance.relevance: The study examines the impact of technological change on labor displacement in the sawmilling industry, highlighting the replacement of labor by capital and its effects on community and ecological sustainability.

design.sample_characteristics: Sawmill workers in British Columbia, Canada, from 1950 to 1985

dependent_variables.displaced: 40% of the sawmill workforce was eliminated during the early 1980s recession.
dependent_variables.unemployment_or_underemployment: 17% of workers were unemployed by 1985, and those who found jobs outside the industry earned 33% less.
dependent_variables.wage_changes: Workers who found jobs outside the industry earned 33% less in 1985 than their sawmill jobs had paid in 1978.

key_themes: Impact of technological change on labor displacement
qualitative_data.narrative_descriptions: The study describes the impact of technological change on sawmill workers, highlighting the reduction in workforce and the increased ecological footprint due to capital-intensive equipment.

historical_context.institutional_context: Labor adjustment policies and studies conducted by Statistics Canada

outcomes.main_findings: The recession of the early 1980s led to a 40% reduction in the sawmill workforce, with increased replacement of labor by capital, resulting in higher productivity and ecological footprint.
outcomes.conclusions: Technological changes in the sawmilling industry have led to significant labor displacement, reduced community viability, and increased ecological pressure.
outcomes.long_term_impacts: The study suggests that the technological changes have long-term impacts on community sustainability and ecological health, with increased migration of younger workers and reduced community stability.
